The action will last 36 months, and will build on Mercy Corps’ previous programmes in Maluku, including those supported by EC funding, as well as the on-going Maluku Economic Recovery Programme 2. Mercy Corps will continue and strengthen relationships with government at the province, district, and local levels, and with private sector stakeholders including agricultural buyers and media. Economic development initiatives will also build as much as possible on the progress made in previous and ongoing actions, and water and sanitation design and health projects will use lessons from Mercy Corps’ ongoing urban slum programme and health activities in other parts of Indonesia. Mercy Corps will use a community mobilization model which has been successful in Maluku and other areas in previous actions, working with communities to prioritize needs, identify solutions, design projects, and monitor implementation. This builds capacity for future proposals as these projects are implemented.

The overall objective of this action is to empower ex-IDPs to integrate into secure, productive, and just communities, supporting sustainable peace and development in Maluku. This will bring conflict-affected households that have been left behind into mainstream development and into greater participation within their communities. The specific objective for this program is to improve access to economic opportunities, water and sanitation facilities, health care, and governance in IDP communities. This is expected to result in: economically sustainable, market-driven livelihoods for IDPs; improved water, sanitation, and health care in IDP communities; and greater social integration of IDPs, including greater capacity for resolution of land issues.
